description: Level 1 corrective drill. Uses the wall to offload bodyweight and guide the vertical spine position. Ideal for athletes with FMS Score 1 who cannot maintain balance in a deep squat.
Level 2 progression. Introduces a single-leg bias while maintaining wall support. Use to identify and correct left/right imbalances in the squat pattern before removing support.
Level 3 activation drill. Adds RNT (Reactive Neuromuscular Training) to pull the athlete into the mistake
Level 4 mobility/stability hybrid. The Figure-4 position challenges hip mobility while the wall ensures safety. Use for athletes needing hip opening combined with pattern work.
Level 5 strength-endurance. Adds external load to the static wall hold. Builds quad capacity and trunk stiffness without the complexity of a free-standing squat.
Level 6 advanced stability. The Zercher position (bar in elbows) forces high anterior core engagement. Excellent for athletes who dump forward in their squat pattern.
Level 7 smoothness drill. The ball reduces friction
Level 1 regression. The band provides lift at the bottom (sticking point)
Level 2 assisted pattern. Uses suspension straps to allow the athlete to "sit back" further than normal
Level 3 tactile cueing. A partner provides specific resistance or assistance. useful for coaching precise torso angles and knee tracking in real-time.
Level 4 transition drill. Using a fixed bar for balance allows the athlete to self-correct stability issues while bearing mostly their own weight.
Level 1 mobility bypass. Elevating the heels removes ankle mobility restrictions. Combined with band assistance
Level 2 patterning. Removes ankle stiffness variable while using the wall for posture. Isolate hip mechanics without fighting ankle restrictions.
Level 3 standard regression. The "Cyclist Squat" position. Allows for a purely vertical torso and deep knee flexion. Diagnostic tool: If they can squat here but not flat
Level 4 loaded regression. Adds anterior load to the heel-raised position. The counterbalance of the weight often cleans up the squat pattern instantly.
Level 5 rhythm drill. Continuous tension squats with elevated heels. Builds vastus medialis strength and knee resilience under control.
Level 6 strength progression. Loading the heel-elevated pattern with dumbbells. Bridges the gap between corrective mobility work and real strength training.
Level 1 baseline pattern. The Prisoner position (hands behind head) forces thoracic extension
Level 2 mobility drill. Starting from a deep hip hinge/stretch position and dropping into the squat. Excellent for mobilizing the hips dynamically.
Level 3 flow/endurance. A high-rep bodyweight movement involving heel elevation and arm swings. Builds coordination and joint flushing.
Level 4 mobility challenge. Facing the wall to force an upright torso. If the athlete leans forward
Level 5 stability bias. One foot slightly forward shifts the center of mass. A regression from single-leg squats that builds independent leg strength.
Level 6 mobility challenge. Feet together demands higher ankle mobility and balance. Use to refine the midline stability of the squat.
Level 7 advanced mobility. A gymnastics-style squat requiring extreme core compression and mobility. Only for athletes with FMS Score 3.
A Level 8 BW SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.
Level 10 isolation. Extreme knee flexion and quad isolation. Not a functional pattern but a high-performance accessory for knee tendon health.
Level 1 hip pattern. Wide stance biases the adductors and allows for a more upright torso. Use for athletes with long femurs who struggle with conventional stance.
Level 2 RNT drill. Bands around knees force the athlete to drive knees out (abduction)
Level 3 loaded patterning. The wide base provides high stability
Level 4 strength. Dumbbell variation allows for independent hand positioning
Level 5 strength. Barbell loading increases systemic demand. The "Hang" position keeps the weight center of mass low
Level 6 anterior core. Holding a plate out front acts as a counterbalance
Level 7 anti-flexion. The Zercher carry forces the athlete to fight against collapsing forward
Level 8 multi-planar. An asymmetrical barbell lift that challenges rotation and anti-rotation stability.
Level 1 depth control. The box provides a tactile target
Level 2 asymmetry check. Single leg box squat. limits the range of motion to a safe height while building unilateral strength.
A Level 3 BOX SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.

exercise_name: KB GOBLET HOLD BOX SQUATS (B/L & U/L)
description: A Level 4 BOX SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.
A Level 5 BOX SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.
A Level 6 BOX SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.
Level 7 overhead stability. Combining the box depth check with the overhead position to ruthlessly audit thoracic and shoulder mobility.
Level 1 foundational strength. The "King of Corrections." The anterior load counterbalances the athlete
Level 2 grip/stability. Holding the KB upside down (bottoms up) demands intense grip and shoulder stability
Level 3 classic loading. The standard for building squat volume safely. Self-limiting: if the upper back rounds
Level 4 lateral bias. Holding the weight to one side (offset) forces the obliques to fight rotation.
A Level 1 KB SQUATS exercise. Targeting specific movement patterns and corrective strategies.
Level 2 front load. Double kettlebells in the rack position compress the chest
Level 3 offset load. One KB racked. The unequal load tries to pull the athlete sideways; the core must fight to stay vertical.
Level 4 anti-lateral flexion. Holding weights at sides (like suitcases). If the core is weak
